event.text: Victory in Europe Day (VE-Day) is declared, ending the European portion of the Second World War

Her Majesty's Canadian ships Annapolis, Columbia, Niagara, St. Clair, St. Croix and St. Francis, ex-American destroyers from the fifty given to Great Britain in exchange for bases, are commissioned into the Royal Canadian Navy
The British Commonwealth Air Training Plan begins operations when students began training at No. 1 Service Flying Training School at Camp Borden, Ontario
a Wellington bomber of No.407 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, sinks the German submarine U-283 in the North Atlantic

the 1st and 2nd Canadian Divisions are authorized as the Canadian Active Service Force. The Royal Canadian Navy, Royal Canadian Navy Reserve and Royal Canadian Navy Volunteer Reserve are placed on active service

Pilot Officer S.R. Henderson, a Canadian serving in No.206 Squadron, Royal Air Force, becomes the first Canadian to participate in an operational sortie during the Second World War when he serves as the lead navigator in a bomber force attacking German warships
Canada declares war on Germany
convoy HX-1 sails from Halifax for Great Britain with a local escort including HMCS St. Laurent and HMCS Saguenay
the Honourable Norman McLeod Rogers is appointed Minister of National Defence

S/L W.I. Clements, attached to No.53 (Blenheim) Squadron, Royal Air Force, becomes the first member of the Royal Canadian Air Force to fly over enemy territory when his squadron makes a long distance reconnaissance flight over Germany
the formation of the Organization and Training Division at RCAF headquarters is authorized
the first Canadian troop convoy sails for Britain escorted out of Halifax by HMC ships Ottawa, Restigouche, Fraser and St. Laurent
the first group of the 1st Canadian Infantry Division arrives in the United Kingdom

the governments of the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand sign an agreement to establish the British Commonwealth Air Training Plan under the supervision of the Royal Canadian Air Force
the second section of the 1st Canadian Infantry Division arrives in the United Kingdom

the awarding of Distinguished Flying Cross (each) to two Canadians serving in the Royal Air Force, Pilot-Officer S.R. Henderson and Wing-Commander J.F. Griffiths, is announced. They are the first Canadians to be decorated during the Second World War
the third Canadian Contingent arrives in Great Britain
No.110 (Army Co-Operation) Squadron sails from Halifax for Britain where it arrives on 25 February, the first Canadian air force squadron to reach Great Britain
No. 1 Initial Training School is opened in Toronto to provide the first training for British Commonwealth Air Training Plan students
No. 1 Air Navigation School was formed at Trenton, Ontario, to provide navigation training for British Commonwealth Air Training Plan students

the first members of No. 112 (Army Co-Operation) Squadron, based in Winnipeg, sail from Canada for Liverpool where they arrive eight days later as the second Royal Canadian Air Force squadron overseas
HMS ships St. Laurent, Restigouche and Skeena sail from Halifax for Britain to join the Allied naval defence forces
No. 1 Air Observer School is opened in Malton, Ontario, to train British Commonwealth Air Training Plan students in air observation duties
Canadian warships come under fire for the first time when HMCS St. Laurent and HMCS Restigouche encounter German warships at St. Valery en Caux
No. 1 (Fighter) Squadron sails from Halifax for Great Britain
the Canadian government declares war on Italy
HMCS St. Laurent and HMCS Restigouche evacuate military personnel from Le Havre, France, exchanging gunfire with German artillery batteries in the process
Canadian troops board transport vessels in St. Malo and Brest to leave France for England after the aborted attempt to support the British and French armies
the last class of Royal Canadian Navy Volunteer Reserve officers graduate from HMCS Stone Frigate
HMCS Fraser is lost after colliding with a British warship, HMS Calcutta in the Bay of Biscay
861 German and Italian prisoners of war are rescued by HMCS St. Laurent after their transport ship was torpedoed on its way to Canada
Les Fusiliers Mont-Royal and The Cameron Highlanders of Ottawa arrive in Iceland to complete the Canadian >Z= Force stationed there
HMCS Skeena rescues the crew of a torpedoed merchant ship, the SS Manipor, in the waters north of Scotland
the Canadian Armoured Corps is authorized
HMS Windflower, the first corvette built in Canada, is commissioned into the Royal Navy with a Canadian crew. She is turned over to the Royal Canadian Navy in 1941
HMCS Margaree is lost in a collision with SS Port Fairy in the North Atlantic
HMCS Bras D'Or founders in the North Atlantic
AZ@ Force, with the exception of The Cameron Highlanders of Ottawa, sails from Iceland for Great Britain
HMCS Collingwood, the first corvette built in Canada for the RCN, is commissioned
the first draft of British Commonwealth Air Training Plan graduates arrive in England for service
HMCS Prince Henry is commissioned as an Armed Merchant Cruiser
HMCS Royal Roads is commissioned as a training establishment for Probationary Sub-Lieutenants
1st Canadian Corps is formed in the United Kingdom under the command of Lieutenant-General A.G.L. McNaughton
HMCS Prince David is commissioned as an Armed Merchant Cruiser
a Commonwealth agreement of 17 December 1939 provides for the future establishment of purely Canadian air force units for newly-trained Canadians to join in Europe
the 5th Canadian Motorcycle Regiment, CASF, (BCD) is converted and redesignated The British Columbia Dragoons

the Rush-Bagot Agreement of 1817, which restricted the number of naval vessels allowed on the Great Lakes, is modified to allow both American and Canadian naval vessels to operate on the Great Lakes in greater numbers
HMCS Otter burns and sinks in the approaches to Halifax
seven Royal Canadian Navy corvettes arrive in St. John's, Newfoundland, to begin operations as the Newfoundland Escort Force
Newfoundland's sea defences are brought under Canadian control with the appointment of Commodore L.W. Murray, RCN, as the commander of Newfoundland Force
warships of the Newfoundland Escort Force begin convoy escort operations in the North Atlantic Ocean
the Canadian government announces its intention to form a Canadian Women's Army Corps
HMCS Wasaga is commissioned, becoming the first Canadian-built Bangor-class minesweeper
the Canadian Women's Auxiliary Air Force is authorized, later becoming the Royal Canadian Air Force (Women’s Division)
HMC Ships Assiniboine and Restigouche escort HMS Prince of Wales, with Prime Minister Winston Churchill aboard, into Placentia Bay, Newfoundland
the Canadian Women’s Army Corps is authorized
HMCS Chambly and HMCS Moose Jaw sink the German submarine U-501 off the coast of Greenland. This is the first U-boat kill made by the Royal Canadian Navy
HMCS Levis (a corvette) is torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic
the University Air Training Squadrons are formed
AC@ Force (Canadian troops under the command of Brigadier J.K. Lawson) sails from Vancouver for Hong Kong
the RCAF is awarded its first George Cross when LAC K.M. Gravell is posthumously awarded the decoration for the attempt to rescue his pilot from their crashed Tiger Moth aircraft
the 1st Armoured Car Regiment (Royal Canadian Dragoons) sails from Canada for Britain as part of the 5th Canadian Armoured Division
HMCS Halifax is commissioned into the RCN
Canada declares war on Romania, Hungary, Finland and Japan
HMCS Windflower is lost after a collision with SS Zypenburg on the Grand Banks of Newfoundland
the United States, Great Britain and other nations declare war on Japan
gallantry shown by Company Sergeant-Major J.R. Osborn, Royal Winnipeg Grenadiers, in action against the Japanese at Hong Kong on this date led to the posthumous award of the Victoria Cross
Hong Kong surrenders to the Japanese forces
the Canadian Women's Auxiliary Air Force is renamed the Royal Canadian Air Force (Women's Division)
HMCS Spikenard is torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic
nine Canadian squadrons (four bomber, four fighter and one coastal) take part in the chase of three German warships in the AChannel Dash@
the Canadian Women's Army Corps is granted full Army status as "a Corps of the Active Militia of Canada"
the first Canadian 'Cruiser' tanks arrive in England
No.413 Squadron begins its transfer from the Shetland Isles to Ceylon to strengthen Allied air defences in the Pacific

Squadron Leader L.J. Birchall and his crew, flying a PBY-5 flying boat, spot a Japanese naval force heading for the island of Ceylon. Their warning allowed the island's defenders to prepare for the Japanese attempt to take the island, an attack which fails. Birchall is later known as "The Saviour of Ceylon"
at least fifteen Canadian members of the Royal Canadian Air Force and the Royal Air Force help the Ceylonese defend the island against the Japanese attempt to conquer it
No. 417 (Spitfire) Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, is transferred from Great Britain to Egypt to support the Allied operations in the Middle East
HMCS St. Croix sinks the German submarine U-90 while on patrol in the North Atlantic Ocean
the Women's Royal Canadian Naval Service is authorized
HMC Ships Wetaskiwin and Skeena sink the German submarine U-588 while on patrol in the North Atlantic Ocean
HMCS Assiniboine sinks the German submarine U-210 while on patrol in the North Atlantic Ocean
a primarily Canadian force conducts a disastrous large-scale raid on the French coastal town of Dieppe
HMC Ships Prince Robert, Prince Henry, Prince David, Dawson and Vancouver leave Esquimalt, British Columbia, to commence operations in the Bering Sea
HMCS Oakville works with American aircraft to sink the German submarine U-94 in the Caribbean Sea
HMCS Raccoon (an armed yacht) is torpedoed and sunk, with the loss of all hands, in the Gulf of St. Lawrence
HMCS Charlottetown (corvette) is torpedoed and sunk in the St. Lawrence
HMCS Ottawa is torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic
the first of sixteen Royal Canadian Navy corvettes sails for the Mediterranean Sea to take part in the North African landings (Operation Torch)

a No.111 Squadron aircraft, Royal Canadian Air Force, flown by S/L K.A. Boomer, destroys a Japanese ARufe@ seaplane over Kiska. This is the only air combat fought by the RCAF in the North American theatre
the Northwest Staging Route is formed as a unit to help connect Alaska and the Yukon by air with supply centres
HMCS Royal Roads becomes the Royal Canadian Naval College and commences training cadets
the Canadian Intelligence Corps is authorized
the active service battalion of the 12th Manitoba Dragoons is redesignated the "18th Armoured Car Regiment (12th Manitoba Dragoons)"
HMC Ships St. Laurent, Chilliwack, Battleford and Napanee sink the German submarine U-356 in the mid-Atlantic
six bombers from No. 427 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, carry out No.6 (RCAF) Bomber Group's first operation, laying mines near the Frisian Islands
HMCS Prince Henry is recommissioned as Landing Ship Infantry (Medium)
a Canadian Army detachment arrives in North Africa
HMCS Ville de Quebec sinks the German submarine U-224 in the western Mediterranean Sea
HMCS Port Arthur sinks the Italian Submarine Tritone in the Mediterranean Sea
the second group of Canadian troops arrive in North Africa
HMCS Louisbourg is torpedoed and sunk by enemy aircraft in an attack on a convoy in the Mediterranean Sea
HMCS Regina sinks the Italian submarine Avorio in the Mediterranean Sea
HMCS Weyburn strikes a mine and sinks off Tangier
HMC Ships Shediac and St. Croix sink the German submarine U-87 in the North Atlantic
the Air Cadet Corps is made a part of the Royal Canadian Air Force
the Flag Officer Atlantic Coast, Royal Canadian Navy, takes over control of all shipping movements in the western North Atlantic under the title of Commander-in-Chief Canadian North West Atlantic
HMCS Drumheller, HMS Lagan and an aircraft from the Royal Canadian Air Force's 423 Squadron combine to sink the German submarine U-753 in the Atlantic Ocean
HMCS Conestoga is commissioned in Galt, Ontario, as the Women's Royal Canadian Naval Service training establishment
HMCS Prince Robert is recommissioned as an anti-aircraft cruiser
HMCS Waskesiu is commissioned into the Royal Canadian Navy, becoming the first of sixty RCN frigates built in Canada
HMCS Sault Ste. Marie is commissioned as the first Algerine-class minesweeper produced for the Royal Canadian Navy
Canadian vessels of the 29th and 65th Motor Torpedo Boat Flotillas conduct raids on the French coast near Cherbourg
Canadian landing craft drop soldiers of the 1st Canadian Division off on the coast of Sicily during the Allied invasion known as Operation Husky
Flying Officer J.H. Turnbull, a No. 600 Royal Air Force Squadron Beaufighter pilot, shoots down three German Ju-88 bombers over Sicily
a Sunderland flying boat from No. 423 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, sinks the German submarine U-489
American and Canadian forces occupy the island of Kiska in the Aleutians
the campaign in Sicily is successfully completed with the capture of the town of Messina
Italy is invaded by Allied troops
beginning on this date and over the next four weeks Royal Canadian Air Force aircraft destroy four U-boats in the Atlantic Ocean
HMS Nabob (an aircraft carrier) is commissioned into the Royal Navy with a Canadian crew and a Royal Air Force complement
HMCS St. Croix (a destroyer) is torpedoed and sunk south of Iceland, the first victim of an acoustic torpedo
HMCS Chedabucto collides with the cable ship Lord Kelvin in the Gulf of St. Lawrence. She is later beached and becomes a total loss
HMCS Snowberry, Calgary and Nene sink U-536 in the North Atlantic
Canadian troops begin their attack on the Italian town of Ortona, an attack successfully completed on 28 December
HMCS Prince David is recommissioned as a Landing Ship Infantry (Medium)
the River Class frigate, HMCS New Glasgow, is commissioned into the Royal Canadian Navy
the Battle of the Moro River in Italy comes to an end
HMCS Camrose and HMS Bayntun sink the German submarine U-757 in the North Atlantic
the Royal Canadian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers are authorized to form
HMS Puncher, an aircraft carrier, is commissioned into the Royal Navy at Vancouver with a Canadian crew, but a British air complement
Canadian troops participate in Operation Veritable in the Reichswald Forest
sixteen Canadian minesweepers, in four divisions of four ships, begin to leave St. John's for British waters to take part in the invasion of Normandy
Motor Torpedo boats of the 29th and 65th (Canadian) Flotillas begin to be commissioned (continues until 31 March)
HMCS Waskesiu sinks the German submarine U-257 in the North Atlantic
HMC Ships St. Catharines, Chilliwack, Gatineau, Fennel and Chaudiere assist Royal Naval warships in the sinking of the German submarine U-744 in the North Atlantic
a Sunderland aircraft from No.422 Squadron attacks and destroys the German submarine U-625
HMC Ships St. Laurent, Owen Sound and Swansea assist Royal Navy warships sink the German submarine U-845 in the North Atlantic
the Canadian Army reaches a peak strength of 495,804 soldiers and support personnel
HMCS Swansea and HMS Pelican combine to sink the German submarine U-448 in the North Atlantic
a Canso aircraft from No. 162 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, sink the German submarine U-432 southwest of Iceland
HMCS Athabaskan and Haida fight two German destroyers off Ile de Bas, France, and destroy one of them. Athabaskan was torpedoed and sunk
HMCS Valleyfield, a frigate, is torpedoed and sunk by the German submarine U-548 in the Atlantic Ocean with a loss of 125 sailors
Allied troops make final push in Battle of Monte Cassino
1st Canadian Division breaks through the Hitler Line
sixteen Royal Canadian Navy minesweepers help clear the English Channel in preparation for the D-Day landings
approximately one hundred and ten Canadian warships participate in the Allied landings in Normandy
HMCS Haida, HMCS Huron and other destroyers from the 10th Destroyer Flotilla sink the German destroyers ZH1 and Z32 in the English Channel
HMCS Haida, HMS Eskimo and a Royal Air Force patrol aircraft sink the German submarine U-971 in the English Channel

Flight Lieutenant David Hornell, a Canso pilot with 162 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, sinks the German submarine U-1225. Hornell's aircraft is also brought down and Hornell dies as a result of his injuries. He is awarded a posthumous Victoria Cross
No. 143 (Typhoon) Wing aircraft, while still based in England, begin using new airstrips in Normandy to rearm and refuel
HMC Ships Ottawa and Kootenay, along with HMS Statice, sink the German submarine U-678 while on patrol in the English Channel
Canadian 3rd Division advances through the city of Caen as part of Operation Greenwood
Canadian troops begin engagements on Verrieres Ridge, suffering large casualties
HMCS Regina is torpedoed and sunk by the German submarine U-667 off the coast of France
HMC Ships Prince David and Prince Henry participate in the Allied landing in southern France, codenamed Operation Dragoon
HMC Ships Ottawa, Kootenay and Chaudiere sink the German submarine U-621 while on patrol in the Bay of Biscay
Major David V. Currie, with the 29th Armoured Reconnaissance Regiment (South Alberta Regiment), is awarded the Victoria Cross for his work in the Falaise Pocket
HMC Ships Ottawa, Kootenay and Chaudiere sink the German submarine U-984 while on patrol in the English Channel B their second combined victory in three days
HMCS Alberni is torpedoed and sunk by the German submarine U-480 in the English Channel
HMS Nabob, a British aircraft carrier with a Royal Canadian Navy crew, is torpedoed in the North Sea and severely damaged
Dieppe is occupied by Canadian troops
HMCS Saint John and HMCS Swansea sink the German submarine U-247 off Land's End, England
HMCS Dunver and HMCS Hespeler sink the German submarine U-484 in Hebridean waters
No.437 (Dakota) Squadron participates in Operation Market Garden, the airborne landings at Eindhoven, by towing gliders and dropping supplies
Calais is captured by Canadian forces
pilots from No.401 Squadron, RCAF, destroy a German Me-262, becoming the first jet-propelled aircraft shot down by the Royal Air Force or the Royal Canadian Air Force
No.6 (RCAF) Group, Bomber Command, deploys its largest sortie of the war with 523 aircraft involved
HMCS Mulgrave strikes a mine off Le Havre, is beached and becomes a total loss
within a period of sixteen hours No.6 (RCAF) Group, Bomber Command, flies a total of 501 Lancaster and Halifax bombers against targets in Duisburg, Germany
HMCS Annan sinks the German submarine U-1006 south of the Faeroes
HMCS Prince Henry and HMCS Prince David engage in landing liberation forces in Greece
HMCS Uganda (later Quebec) is commissioned, becoming
HMCS Skeena becomes stranded near Reykjavik, Iceland, becoming a total loss
end of the Battle of the Scheldt
the Aircraft Detection Corps of civilian volunteer observers is disbanded
HMCS Shawinigan is torpedoed by a German submarine in Cabot Strait and sunk with all hands
Canadian troops storm the Lamone River defences in Italy
HMCS Clayoquot is torpedoed by a U-boat and sinks in the Halifax approaches
HMCS St. Thomas sinks the German submarine U-877 in the North Atlantic
Flight-Lieutenant R.J. Audet, No.411 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, shoots down five German fighters during a patrol in the Rhine area
Second-Lieutenant C.J.W. Taylor, No.407 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, sinks the German submarine U-772 with depth charges
HMCS Ehkoli, a former Royal Canadian Navy patrol boat, is recommissioned in the RCN as a survey vessel
Nos.1 and 3 Training Commands, Royal Canadian Air Force, are disbanded and replaced by No.1 Air Command with headquarters at Trenton, Ontario
No.9 (Transport) Group, Royal Canadian Air Force, is formed to control air transport within the air force
First Canadian Army opens an offensive at the north end of the German Siegfried Line southeast of Nijmegen in order to clear the area between the Maas and Rhine rivers
Canadian troops capture the town of Cleve in Germany
five Motor Torpedo Boats of the Canadian 29th Flotilla burn in Ostende harbour
HMCS St. John sinks the German submarine U-309 off the northeast coast of Scotland
HMCS Trentonian is torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine in the English Channel
HMCS Uganda arrives in Sydney, Australia, to join the British Pacific Fleet

the First Canadian Corps takes over the sector along the Waal River in Holland upon its arrival from the Italian theatre of war. As a result, both Canadian corps now form part of the First Canadian Army
HMCS Guysborough is torpedoed and sunk by a German U-boat off Ushant
HMCS New Glasgow sinks the German submarine U-1003 off Lough Foyle, Northern Ireland
Corporal F.G. Topham, Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps, is awarded the Victoria Cross for his actions in support of 1st Canadian Parachute Battalion east of the Rhine River, Germany
HMCS Conestoga, the Women's Royal Canadian Naval Service training establishment, is paid off
the First Canadian Army crosses the Rhine and captures the town of Zevenaar, and reaches the town of Zutphen
the First Canadian Army clears out the town of Almelo
the First Canadian Army reaches the Dutch coast near Leeuwarden
HMCS Esquimalt is torpoeded and sunk in the waters off of Halifax
HMCS Ontario, a cruiser, is commissioned
the cruiser HMCS Uganda sails with an American task force to bombard Japanese airfields as part of the Okinawa campaign
units of the First Canadian Army accept the surrender of German forces at Bad Zwischenahn, Germany
All German military forces surrender to the Allied Forces in Europe
the prefix ‘Royal’ is granted for the Canadian Armoured Corps by the King
